Noise playback will continue after exit.

White noise has equal power at all frequencies. Human hearing is however logarithmically spaced, where a doubling of frequency (an octave) is perceived the same regardless of the frequency. This makes white noise seem quite harsh and high pitched.
Pink noise has a logarithmically even distribution of power. Since each octave contains the same amount of power it is received as a naturally smooth noise by the human ear.

Red noise, also known as Brown noise (due to the particle physics applications in Brownian motion), has a power density that decreases with increasing frequency. It is perceived to be the most pleasant and is often used while studying or as a baby sleep sound.
